key_points: President Joe Biden has issued an executive order to end Donald Trump's travel ban on noncitizens from 13 countries on his first day in office.
The travel ban, known as the "Muslim ban," first enacted in January 2017, targeted countries deemed security threats, significantly limiting legal immigration.
Originally affecting majority-Muslim countries, the ban was expanded to include six more countries in February 2020.
The policy has faced criticism for being discriminatory and was challenged in court numerous times before being upheld by the Supreme Court in its third version.
Over 41,000 people have been denied visas due to the ban, with waivers being difficult to obtain.
Enrollment from affected countries in U.S. educational institutions and certain professions like healthcare has seen a significant decline.
The rescinding of the ban fulfills one of Biden's campaign promises on immigration policy.
Critics argue the ban did not enhance national security and damaged the U.S.'s international relationships.
Former intelligence officials and ambassadors have criticized the ban for its focus on Islamist terrorism and the negative impact on U.S. national security.
Immigrant advocates urge further action from the Biden administration and Congress to dismantle Trump's immigration policies and barriers.
spokespersons: Elizabeth Neumann (Former Assistant Secretary for Counterterrorism and Threat Prevention, Homeland Security Department)
